message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest pes anserine bursitis, which can cause pain in the anteromedial part of the tibial plateau. The negative McMurray's test and lack of tenderness with other knee movements indicate that a meniscus tear is unlikely. Prepatellar bursitis would cause tenderness in the front of the knee, which is not reported by the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms of pain in the anteromedial part of the tibial plateau suggest pes anserine bursitis, which is inflammation of the bursa located between the tibia and the hamstring tendons on the medial side of the knee. The lack of tenderness in other parts of the knee and negative McMurray's test rules out meniscus tears. Prepatellar bursitis would cause tenderness over the kneecap, which is not present in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and physical exam suggest pes anserine bursitis, which is characterized by pain and tenderness at the proximal and medial aspect of the tibia. The pain is often worsened by activities such as climbing stairs or running. The lack of tenderness or other symptoms related to the knee joint make meniscus tear an unlikely diagnosis. Prepatellar bursitis typically causes tenderness over the front of the knee, while the patient's symptoms are more medial.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms point towards Pes anserine bursitis, which is an inflammation of the bursa on the medial side of the knee joint. The tenderness on palpation of the anteromedial part of the tibial plateau and the absence of positive signs in McMurray's test eliminate Lateral meniscus tear and Medial meniscus tear as the possible diagnoses. Prepatellar bursitis is an inflammation of the bursa on the anterior knee, which is not consistent with the location of the patient's pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, especially the tenderness at the anteromedial part of the tibial plateau, suggest Pes anserine bursitis. Lateral and medial meniscus tears typically cause joint line tenderness or locking/ catching sensations. Prepatellar bursitis causes tenderness above the patella.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and physical exam suggest pes anserine bursitis. The patient has pain in the anteromedial part of the tibial plateau, which is where the pes anserine tendon inserts. The other options are less likely as there is no tenderness in other parts of the knee and McMurray's test is negative.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has tenderness to pressure on the anteromedial part of the tibial plateau and no other parts of the knee are tender, which suggests Pes anserine bursitis. Lateral and medial meniscus tears will produce other specific symptoms, while Prepatellar Bursitis produces a tender and swollen knee cap.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest pes anserine bursitis as the pain is localized to the anteromedial part of the tibial plateau and there is no tenderness with other knee movements or McMurray’s test. Lateral and medial meniscus tears would have other associated symptoms and findings. Prepatellar bursitis would have tenderness over the kneecap.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest Pes anserine bursitis, which is inflammation of the tendons and bursae located at the insertion of the Pes anserinus. The tenderness on the anteromedial part of the tibial plateau is a common finding. The negative McMurray's test suggests that there is no meniscal tear. There is also no tenderness in other parts of the knee, ruling out prepatellar bursitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical exam shows no abnormalities in the hips or left lower extremity, making it unlikely that the pain is referred. The tenderness elicited with pressure on the anteromedial part of the tibial plateau suggests pes anserine bursitis, which is located on the medial aspect of the proximal tibia. The negative McMurray's test makes it unlikely that there is a meniscus tear, and there is no tenderness with knee movements that would suggest a bursitis in another location, such as prepatellar bursitis.
